title: 'add -d. .' shows confusing error on a moved file

labels.name: fix-implemented
labels.description: A fix is available, but has not been merged or released, yet.

body:
[ +cc @AdinaWagner, who ran into this ]

When trying to add a moved file, `datalad add -d. .` spits out an error, although the resulting commit seems fine.  The `-d.`  is required to trigger the issue because otherwise `AnnotatedPaths` is called with `modified=None` and the problematic [`get_modified_subpaths` call][0] is avoided.

I haven't dug any deeper or thought about possible fixes.  I suppose this issue is resolved with datalad-revolution, so it may not be worth fixing in the meantime.

```sh
set -x

datalad create add-moved
cd add-moved
touch foo && datalad add foo
git tag base

# Works fine when a dataset isn't specified
mv foo foo_moved && datalad add .
# add(ok): /tmp/add-moved/foo_moved (file)
# add(ok): /tmp/add-moved (dataset)
# save(ok): /tmp/add-moved (dataset)
# action summary:
#   add (ok: 2)
#   save (ok: 1)

# Fails if a dataset is specified
git reset --hard base
mv foo foo_moved && datalad add -d. .
# [WARNING] Running add resulted in stderr output: git-annex: /tmp/add-moved/foo not found
# git-annex: add: 1 failed
#
# add(ok): foo_moved (file)
# [ERROR  ] not found [add(/tmp/add-moved/foo)]
# add(error): foo (file) [not found]
# save(ok): /tmp/add-moved (dataset)
# action summary:
#   add (error: 1, ok: 1)
#   save (ok: 1)

# Commit was create, though
git diff HEAD^-
# diff --git a/foo b/foo_moved
# similarity index 100%
# rename from foo
# rename to foo_moved
```

[0]: https://github.com/datalad/datalad/blob/dd3ccd6c18e5d1372e6c490881ca35e3af4a8fe3/datalad/interface/annotate_paths.py#L556
